persons.name: Thales
persons.description: Ancient Greek pre-Socratic philosopher from Miletus in Ionia, Asia Minor.

persons.name: Parmenides
persons.description: a pre-Socratic Greek philosopher from Elea in Magna Graecia.

persons.name: Pericles
persons.description: Athenian general and politician who supported the arts and literature.

persons.name: Xenophanes
persons.description: Greek philosopher, theologian, poet, and critic of Homer from Ionia who travelled throughout the Greek-speaking world in early Classical Antiquity. As a poet, Xenophanes was known for his critical style, writing poems that are considered among the first satires.

places.name: Sicily
places.description: Sicily is the largest and most populous island in the Mediterranean Sea and one of the twenty regions of Italy.

places.name: Sicily
places.description: Sicily is the largest and most populous island in the Mediterranean Sea and one of the twenty regions of Italy.

persons.name: Heraclitus
persons.description: An ancient Greek pre-Socratic philosopher from the city of Ephesus, which was then part of the Persian Empire.

persons.name: JesusChrist
persons.description: The central figure of Christianity; a first-century Jewish preacher and religious leader.

persons.name: Pythagoras
persons.description: Pythagoras of Samos was an ancient Ionian Greek philosopher, polymath, and the eponymous founder of Pythagoreanism. Believed in the primacy of number.

persons.name: Leucippus
persons.description: a pre-Socratic Greek philosopher. He is traditionally credited as the founder of atomism, which he developed with his student Democritus. Leucippus divided the world into two entities: atoms, indivisible particles that make up all things, and the void, the nothingness that exists between the atoms.

places.name: Abdera
places.description: a municipality in the Xanthi regional unit of Thrace, Greece. In classical antiquity, it was a major Greek polis on the Thracian coast.

places.name: Athens
places.description: Athens is the capital city of Greece.

persons.name: Socrates
persons.description: Greek philosopher whose work survives mostly through the writings of his pupil Plato. Executed by the democratic Athenian state for sedition.

persons.name: Aristophanes
persons.description: a comic playwright or comedy-writer of ancient Athens and a poet of Old Attic Comedy.

persons.name: Socrates
persons.description: Greek philosopher whose work survives mostly through the writings of his pupil Plato. Executed by the democratic Athenian state for sedition.

persons.name: Plato
persons.description: A pupil of Socrates, much of Plato's large corpus of surviving philosophical texts are written in the form of Socratic dialogues. He espoused a philosophical idealism including the primacy of mathematics and an anti-democratic political philosophy because of the execution of Socrates. Plato's writings have been, and are, so influential that all subsequent philosophy has been described as footnotes to Plato.

persons.name: Plato
persons.description: A pupil of Socrates, much of Plato's large corpus of surviving philosophical texts are written in the form of Socratic dialogues. He espoused a philosophical idealism including the primacy of mathematics and an anti-democratic political philosophy because of the execution of Socrates. Plato's writings have been, and are, so influential that all subsequent philosophy has been described as footnotes to Plato.

persons.name: Aristotle
persons.description: A pupil of Plato's whose philosophical idealism he came to reject, arguing instead for the primacy of observations of natural phenomena. He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. Aristotle's writings became the main way the natural world was understood from the Middle Ages to the seventeenth century, especially in the universities.

places.name: Arabian Peninsula
places.description: a peninsula in West Asia, situated northeast of Africa on the Arabian Plate. It includes the territories of includes Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Yemen, as well as southern Iraq and Jordan. In the classical era, the Sinai Peninsula was also considered a part of Arabia.

persons.name: Alexander III

persons.description: Greek writer most famous for his parallel lives of Greek and Roman statesmen and military leaders.

persons.name: Archimedes
persons.description: Ancient Greek mathematician, physicist, engineer, astronomer and inventor from Syracuse in Sicily.

persons.name: Hiero II
persons.description: The Greek tyrant of Syracuse. He was a former general of Pyrrhus of Epirus and an important figure of the First Punic War. He figures in the story of Archimedes shouting "Eureka".

persons.name: Marcus ClaudiusMarcellus
persons.description: an important Roman military leader. He is noted for having conquered the fortified city of Syracuse in a protracted siege during which Archimedes was killed, despite Marcellus ordering the soldiers under his command not to harm him.

persons.name: Euclid
persons.description: An ancient Greek mathematician, geometer and logician. Considered the "father of geometry", he is chiefly known for the Elements treatise, which established the foundations of geometry that largely dominated the field until the early 19th century.

places.name: Alexandria
places.description: The second largest city in Egypt and the largest city on the Mediterranean coast. Alexandria was the intellectual and cultural centre of the ancient Mediterranean for much of the Hellenistic age and late antiquity, particularly famous for its lighthouse and library.

places.name: Pharos
places.description: The Lighthouse of Alexandria, or the Pharos Lighthouse, was built on an island offshore from the Nile Delta, between 280-247 BCE. It was estimated to be 100m high. It was damaged by earthquakes and abandoned as a ruin in 1323 CE.

persons.name: Eratosthenes
persons.description: a Greek polymath: a mathematician, geographer, poet, astronomer, and music theorist. He was the chief librarian at the Library of Alexandria.

persons.name: Aristarchus
persons.description: an ancient Greek astronomer and mathematician who presented the first known heliocentric model that placed the Sun at the center of the known universe.

places.name: Alexandria
places.description: The second largest city in Egypt and the largest city on the Mediterranean coast. Alexandria was the intellectual and cultural centre of the ancient Mediterranean for much of the Hellenistic age and late antiquity, particularly famous for its lighthouse and library.

persons.name: Hipparchus
persons.description: a Greek astronomer, geographer, and mathematician. He is considered the founder of trigonometry, but is most famous for his incidental discovery of the precession of the equinoxes.

persons.name: ClaudiusPtolemy
persons.description: An Alexandrian mathematician, astronomer, astrologer, geographer, and music theorist. His Almagest supporting a geocentric view of the world was not seriously contradicted until the work of Copernicus.

places.name: Alexandria

persons.description: An Alexandrian mathematician, astronomer, astrologer, geographer, and music theorist. His Almagest supporting a geocentric view of the world was not seriously contradicted until the work of Copernicus.

persons.name: FrancisBacon
persons.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. Aristotle's writings became the main way the natural world was understood from the Middle Ages to the seventeenth century, especially in the universities.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.
